Black Traytors to their Country, Friends to you.

sp.speaker: Beauf.
sp.l: For you win Provinces, as Hell gains Souls;
'Tis by corrupting them you make them yours:
They might defie your malice were they faithful▪
But first you enslave them to their own base Passions;
And afterwards to yours.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Ha! My Mother's Slave! What wouldst thou? [A part to him.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Your Mother—

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Well—

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Stands with her threatning Dagger in her hand.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Oh Horrour! Horrour!
My fancy cannot bear the murdring thought.
Tell her, her harsh command shall be obey'd.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Now Gentlemen, we to our business come;
Such a Community as you propose
We utterly reject, because that Union
Would first corrupt our Angians, then enslave them;
The only Treaty to which we descend.

sp.speaker: Beauf.
sp.l: How Ulamar.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Oh Englishman, your Separate Interest here
Is but too obvious.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Hold Frenchman?
My Friend, no more, anon thou shalt be satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Beauf.
sp.l: In the mean while—

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: No more, by Holy Friendship I adjure thee,
Thou shalt be satisfy'd; but to our business;
The Treaty to which we descend is this;
A Treaty of Commerce between us and you;
And a Cessation of Hostilities between our selves and you,
And your Confederates
The Hurons, and exchange of all the Captives:
To this you agree?

sp.speaker: Zeph.
sp.l: I do, for this is Angies Interest.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: And you?

sp.speaker: 2 Fr.
sp.l: And we.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: And this to observe most solemnly you Swear;
By all that's awful in yon glittering Sky,
And all that's binding in the World below.

sp.speaker: 2. Fr.
sp.l: We Swear: And you?

sp.speaker: Zeph.
sp.l: We Swear.

sp.speaker: 1. Emb.
sp.l: So then 'tis done; The English are dislodg'd?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: They need not fright thee;
A League from hence they lie entrench'd to Night,
And towards new York to morrow take their way.

sp.speaker: 2. Emb.
sp.l: And all your Angians have laid down their Arms.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: E're we began to Treat, the English march'd,
And ours dispers'd according to our words.

sp.speaker: 1. Emb.
sp.l: The Remnant of the Night, lets wast in Joy then.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: The publick Deputies in yon Apartment
Attend to Entertain you.

sp.speaker: 1. Emb.
sp.l: We wait on you.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: We follow you.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: What turnst thou from thy Friend, O Beaufort, Beaufort.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: What hast thou done fond Youth?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: O Look not with that Mornful coldness on me,
Thou art my Benefactor, Father, Friend;
'Tis by thy Generous Friendship I have Liv'd;
Alas I cannot bear the freezing Gloom
That's on thy Brow, it chills me to the Heart.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Reflect on what thou hast done

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Oh speak not Beaufort in that Cruel Tone!
Where is my Friend, my Warm, my tender Friend,
For in thy alter'd Meen I see him not,
Nor hear him in thy Voice.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Thou hast betray'd him, lost him.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Not for the World, I would not loose my Beaufort
What 'ere I did, thy Friend was forc'd to do.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Forc'd?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Yes, forc'd, and with the only dreadful Force
That could compel my Soul,
My Mothers Life depended on the Deed.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Yes, yes, I guest the Cause;
Ay, This is what has Captivated Europe,
Where their Domestick Interest most prefer
Before the Weal and Honour of their Country,
Tho' private good on publick Weal depends,
And he who for his House betrays his Country,
Betrays his Family, Betrays his Children,
All his Posterity to shameful Ruin,
And makes them Poor, Precarious, Abject, Base,
Instead of Happy, Rich, or Great, or Brave;
And this, fond Youth, thou wilt too surely fin'd

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Oh spare me Beaufort, spare me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Yes, I have done, this is Revenge enough,
For one who Loves thee.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Oh that blest sound! How it revives my Soul?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: This for a Friend, is Chastisement enough;
Or if thy Fault asks more, thy new Allies
Too surely will inflict it, for their Friends:
Their Friends are they, who feel their Barbarous Hands,
Most Grievous and most Bloody.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Nay, now thou Chid'st again;

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Oh! No, my Friend, my Happiness, my Glory.
'Tis now that I would chiefly shew I Love thee;
For since with so much Tenderness, we have Liv'd,
And Fate at last obliges us to part,
And that for ever, let us part in Love.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: What must we part?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Part Ulamar? Why that's the very thing
Thy new Allies design'd.
'Tis by dividing old and Faithful Friends
That they oft ruine both; 'tis their old Cheat.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: But sure thou did'st not say for Ever?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Too probably for ever!

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Curst unforeseen Calamity! But when?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: This moment.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: This moment! 'Tis Impossible.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: This moment to my Troops, I take my way,
I doubt the French, and dare no longer Stay:
Adieu my Friend?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: For ever Beaufort! Let us in part Hope.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: England severely will Revenge this Peace,
And leave the Angians to their new Allies,
And to their Mercy, which is dreadful Cruelty;
And I as England's faithful Son am bound,
To enter into all her Sentiments.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: But yet thou wilt not Hate me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Oh never, never, 'tis not in my Pow'r;
My valued Friend, adieu!

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: This partings death to me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: What is't to me then?
This Evening I resign'd Irene to thee,
Did that declare a Vulgar Friendship, say.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Oh no! A Matchless, unexampled one.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: And yet thou hast depriv'd me of thy self too,
Irene now is thine, and thou art Hers;
She soon will comfort thee, for Beaufort's Abscence;
But only Death will drive away my Grief,
For I shall never never see thee more.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Why then thou wilt not sure begone to Night;
For I have still ten Thousand things to say.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I must be gone, ev'n now I must begone;
I doubt the French, and dare no longer stay,
For my Brave Troops may all er'e morn be lost.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: But 'tis a Gloomy and Tempestous Night;
And thou hast a long League to March alone,
And yet thou say'st, there may be danger near.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Oh I have lost all that I held most Dear;
Th' entirely Wretched, need no danger Fear.

div2.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: BEaufort; thy loss sits Heavy on my Soul!
For I shall never see thy like again;
In whom the Flame of English Spirit shone,
A Greatness that adorns those generous Nations,
That never Basely yet resign'd their Liberty!
A Magnanimity unknown to Slaves!
Oh how unlike our new Confederates he?
But yet this Night I will have Truce with Grief;
This Night I Conscerate to Love and Joy:
Hast then, my Fairest, my espous'd, O hast!
And cheer thy Languishing Impatient Ulamar.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: 'Tis late, and we will leave thee to thy Bride.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Well Madam! Now I hope you are Satisfy'd!

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Not thou thy self art more.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: You own then, I have Reason to be satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Oh thou art Blest above the Race of men,
Possessing all that's Good, and all that's Fair.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: You have heard Irene talk, which till this Day,
Your strange Aversion never would permit you:
What think you of her Mind?

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Oh 'tis the very Mind of all her Sex,
That's fit to Animate that Lovely Person,
An Angel fit to inform that Glorious Sphear;
Prepare thy self to Morrow for new Transports,
For then thou shalt behold the best of Fathers,
And I the best of Loveas in a Husband.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: He'll not refuss'd to see Irene sure,
Tho' born an Angian.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: O no, My Son, He will not only see.
But will be Ravish'd with the Matchless sight;
For thou hast Chose exactly to his wish;
And thy choice answers to the Fair Idea,
The Lovely Image, and the perfect mind
Which his rich Fancy form'd for thee:
Once more, ten Thousand Blessings on you both.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Come to my Arms, thou Charming wish of Souls!
The happy Night, th' Auspicious hour is come
That I so long have wish'd, so long Dispair'd to see;
Make but this Bliss perpetual, O ye Powr's!
I ask no more, for I am Blest as you.
What's this? By all the Immortal Pow'rs in Tears!
And art thou Griev'd, that thy poor Lovers Blest?
Is this thy Constancy? Is this thy Flame?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: My Ulamar! Since I declar'd my Love
When Decency almost forbad the sound:
Now Heav'n has made it Duty, I must own
My Passion, is my Darling Pride of Soul;
And never can Irene more be pleas'd
Than when her Lovely Ulamar is Blest:
But ah, a sadness sits upon my Soul,
A fatal load, that weighs it down from Bliss,
To which it would aspire, a black Presage
That wispers to me, I must loose thee Ulamar,

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: The Gods forbid, that I should loose Irene,
Why shou'd my Love give way to such a thought?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Oh Ulamar! My Happiness! My Life!
The blissful Days and Hours that I expect:
Now Joyn'd in happy Nuptial League with thee,
Is surely what offends th' Immortal Pow'rs;
Such Bliss is far above a Mortal state,
For we should Live and be as Gods my Love
And that the Wrathful Pow'rs above deny.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: This is meer Melancholly fancy all.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Ah me! what dreadful Groan was that, as if
A Thousand wretches, in one Breath expir'd:
The Demons of the Air, sure catch my Grief
Confirming my Presage.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: 'Tis Fancy all, or next to Fancy wind,
That raging makes the bending Forest roar,
No Dearest, if th' Immortal Pow'rs are Angry,
'Tis not with thee, for thou art Spotless all,
In whom not Earth, nor Heav'n a fault can see;
No, 'tis with me who see all Heav'n before me,
And yet delay to tast of Immortality.
For Oh! I talk, I loiter out the Night
Too, too Inestimable to be lost
In words: If we must talk, to Bed my Fair,
Where I shall whisper something to thy Soul
That is a Secret for the Gods and thee.
O those bewitching Blushes! How they dart
Caelestial Fire thro' all my Trembling frame.
If there is cause to Fear th' Immortal Pow'rs
Should Snatch thee from me, let us Live to Night,
This Blissful Night whole Ages let us Live.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Bless me ye Pow'rs! What dismal Screem is that?
Heard you not something?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Plainly I heard, and wonder what if means.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Hark! hark! Another shreek.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: And now they groan.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Now shouts of Joy Succeed.
And now a Noise of Murder and of Fire.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Ha! What art thou, thus mangled, and thus Pale?
Can'st thou be Arimat?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: The poor remains of Arimat.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Alas! Thou art Dying.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Yes, there were two things
That I had left to do in this frail World;
To save thee Ulamar, and then to Dye.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Surprise has so Confounded all my Pow'rs
That I want force to ask thee, who has done this.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Who but our new Allies.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: The French?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: The Faithless French.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Impossible! Thou rav'st poor Dying Arimat.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: I would to Heav'n I did: the Perjur'd French
Rallying their routed Troops, came back by stealth,
And for twelve Hours, insidiously sat down
Under the Brow of yonder Northern Mount,
And there sat Brooding o're their black design.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: How know'st thou this?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Aloud they boast it thro' our Flaming streets,
And how with ease by Night, they gain'd a Place,
Trusting to Solemn Oaths so lately Sworn;
Bury'd in Sleep, and quite dissolv'd in Luxury.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Confusion! Angiae on the Brink of Ruin,
And I stand loitering here, to Arms, to Arms.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Hold, Ulamar, I came not for that purpose;
'Tis now to late to Fight; for all our Angians,
Except a few, are Fled, or Slain, or taken.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: And why had I no sooner Notice?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Alas! All this has in few Minuets past,
For we were most without Defence surpriz'd,
Depending on this Nights so Solemn Treaty.
Fly while thou can'st, Brave Ulamar, Oh Fly!
A dauntless handful still, of our Brave Warriours
With Matchless Valour keep the Dogs at Bay;
Yet they but Fight, to give thee time to Fly,
Their zeal to save their wretched sinking Country;
Against vast Numbers: For a while sustains them,
That they may save in thee, the Prop of Liberty,
The great support of all th' Iroquian Tribes,
The only hope of Angiae.—
My fainting Limbs, no longer will support me;
Receive me Earth, the Refuse now of Nature. [Falls.
Fly Ulamar, e're yet it be to late,
Or thou and Angiae are like me no more. [Dies.

sp.speaker: Iri.
sp.l: He Dies.
Begone my Love, without delay begone.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: And where alas wilt thou go?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: To Life or Death I'll follow thee.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: To Life thou can'st not, 'tis impossible,
For I must Scale the Palisades t'escape.
The French possess the Gates; no, Flight for me,
No, I must Die; but will not tamely Fall;
Nor unreveng'd, to Arms, to arms.

sp.speaker: Zep.
sp.l: O Horrour! Horrour! 'tis too late my Son.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: My Father bleeding? Stream my Eyes like fountains.

sp.speaker: Zep.
sp.l: Angiae has been, and we are now no more.
Die Ulamar, and thou Irene Die:
If thou would'st Dye, as thou hast Liv'd with Honour,
Die quickly, while thy wretched Country-men:
The few remains of Angians scarse defend
The Entrance to this place—I can no more. [Dies.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: He dies, he dies, and Heav'n looks calmly on.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Hark! hark! they come, Retire my Love retire,
Now for the welcome that such guests deserve.

div3.head: Scene 6.
div3.stage: Ula. Ire. Front. Mir. Officers and Souldiers. Fight.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Ha! Who art thou so young, yet do'st such wonders,
Thou art truly Brave by Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: So Brave, that 'tis a most Opprobrious shame
That he should poorly be opprest by Odds:
My Lord, give orders that your Men retire,
I am alone sufficient. (Advancing.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Hold Kinsman, Miramont I charge thee hold.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Ha! Miramont!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes, what hast thou to say to Miramont?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Come on, and twice in one Revolving Sun
Receive thy Life from me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ha! my Preserver?
These are the only Arms I'll use with thee; [Embraces.
Resign thy Sword, and thy Defence to me:
This is Count Frontenac our Captain General,
Allied to me in Blood, allied in Soul,
Dearer then all Relations as my Friend,
And I have made Him Swear my Brave Deliverer
Should be both Safe and Free.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: This morning by thy Looks I thought thee Honest,
And in thy words a Generous Mind appears,
How comes it that thou Vilely could'st descend
To share the Guilt of this Perfidious act?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I share it not,
For I return'd not to attack the Angians,
But to deliver thee:
Know I detested this Perfidious Deed;
But what can one against a Multitude,
Or the Commands of Arbitary sway?
Our General too detests it in his Heart.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: And yet performs it? What a Riddle's this?

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: I dare not disobey Superiour Pow'r.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: In all new France no Pow'r excells thy own.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: From Europe the severe Command arriv'd.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: But why this odious Treason?

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Thrice have I orders from the Court receiv'd,
To spare no Force, nor Art, nor Cost, nor Fraud
To seize upon the General of the Angians.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Ha! Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: 'Tis He's the furious Thunderbolt of War,
That maks th' unconquer'd Iroquois so dreadful,
To us more Mortal then a General Plague,
Consumes our Colonies, destroys our Men,
Slaughters our faithful Friends and our Allies;
Nay Vows t' Extirpate all the Gallick Race;
Their very Memories, and their Names from Canada.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: D'ost thou know Him!

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: His Deeds have made him, too much known to France,
But for his Face, I never yet beheld it,
Yet by the Angians obstinate defence
Before this place: I thought to have found him here,
Thou may'st discover where he lies conceal'd,
For the other Slaves are obstinately Dumb.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: What would'st thou with him?

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: When I have got him in my Pow'r, he dies,
For so my Orders from the Court require,
And I have Sworn, he shall not Live an hour.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Then rashly hast thou Sworn, and thou art Perjur'd:

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Presumtuous Boy!

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Yes, thou art Perjur'd
For thou hast Sworn to thy Relation there,
The General of the Angians shou'd be free.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Yet more presumptuous!
Would'st thou, who art not old enough to serve;
Would thou pretend to lead an Army?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Yes;
They whom the Gods Inspire are ne're too young,
And they have set up me, to save my Country;
And drive out Tyrants, from this Indian World.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: I see thou hast a Soul above thy years,
And that exalted Soul must scorn a Lye;
Thou art the General then, since thou hast said it,
Here take him Guards, and lead him to his Fate.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Confusion! Hold there! What do you mean my Lord?

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: I mean to take his Life.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: But that you must not.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: How; must not?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No; shall not, dare not.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: And who dares hinder me? I here am Absolute.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You have given your solemn Oath, and dare not break it.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: I had given the King my Solemn word before:
I'st not the Kings Command?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No, 'tis unjust, the King can do no Wrong:
He who Commands injustice, is no King;
Nor are we bound t' Obey.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Always a Male-content!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Am I alone?
Are there not Thousands here in Caneda?
O would you kearken to great Natures call.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Away! I hear thee not,
But for this Angian, instantly he dies
Take him away there.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The Dog who first lays hold of him shall Perish;
As long as I have Life, I will defend him.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Hold there!
That Life is forfeited if I wou'd take it;
But fondly thou presum'st upon my Love.
Ungrateful Miramont! Art thou my Friend?
Who seek'st my Infamy, who seek'st my Ruin?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I seek your Honour.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: My Honour! mind your own.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I will, I do:
Whose Honour here is more concern'd than mine;
Depending on your Faith, I gave my Honour
To see this Noble youth both Safe and Free;
And 'twas the trust that he repos'd in that.
Made him deliver up his Sword to me:
I have giv'n my Honour, and I will maintain it;
And yours, tho' you neglect it.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Ha! have a care!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I will have no care; here take my Life,
'Tis that I know you Thirst for, and 'tis yours.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: I am but too tender of it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: To tenderness thy Souls an utter Stranger:
He tender of my Life, who takes my Honour!

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Upon thy Life no more? Come yet I am thy Friend.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You never were.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: O thou wilt Rouse the Lyon till he tears thee.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Here let him tear me! What's this wretched Breast,
Without the unsullied Jewel, of the which
You basely would deprive it.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Ha! Am I then defy'd, here Seize him Guards,
Kill him if he Resists: Hold, Gods he Bleeds!

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis the Blood so oft I've shed for you.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: It is indeed; that thought coolls all my rage:
What woulst thou have at last? My utter ruine?
Come, thou shalt have thy wish.
But wilt thou then believe I am thy Friend?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How can you think that he desires your Ruine,
Who has so oft shed his best Blood to serve you;
No, I will die before I will see that;
Nay he shall die too:
But come my Lord, consider e're you act;
Behold this noble Youth with all your Eyes,
Reflect upon his Worth, survey his Person.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: I have consider'd all.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Is not his Courage more than common?

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Heroick.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: His Magnanimity?

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Godlike.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: His Person?

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: The pleasure of my Eyes;
And were he not my Country's mortal Foe▪
How I could doat on such uncommon worth.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Come, come, my Lord, your Country's Foes are they,
Who trample under foot its Native Rights:
Not they who Fight against Tyrannick Sway;
But all this while this Fair one we neglect:
Yet She is Fair—

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: A Miracle of Beauty;

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And seems to have a Soul above her Sex:
Look how her mournful Eyes move melting pity!
In which the greatness of her mind appears,
That strugles to repress her mighty Woe;
So soft, so young, so tender; yet so firm!
By her this wretched Youth should be a Lover.
Is She thy Mistriss or thy Wife?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Oh thou hast found a way to break my Heart;
This stubborn Heart which Fate could not subdue!
For when I think of what She undergoes,
In my tumultous Breast it sinks and dies.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Is she thy Mistriss or thy Wife? Nay speak.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Oh cruel Fate! Was ever Woe like mine?
Alas! She's both my Mistriss and my Wife

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: We are no strangers to the Pow'r of Love,
Nor to the Grief that hapless Love attends;
We know how Cruel 'tis, to be thus torn
From all that's precious to our Bleeding Hearts;
And shall we inflict those piercing woes on others?
My Lord, my Lord, by powerful Love I charge you,
Whose Captive you have been, and yet remain,
Or is the Object of your Flame forgot?

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: O Never, never shall she be forgot!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Then by great Love, whose Captive you remain,
I here conjure you, spare this Captive pair;
By the remembrance of that Lovely Object,
By all the Bliss you Enjoy'd with her so long;
By all your bitter Woe for her sad Loss,
And by those sighs you now profoundly draw
From your sad Heart, th' Exhaustless source of Woe.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: O Miramont forbear, my Friend forbear,
Thou hast rouz'd the Vultour slumbering in my Breast,
That gnaws my Heart asunder.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: If Seperations hard to you my Lord,
Who long possest the Darling of your Heart,
And who from Life's Meridian now decline;
What must it be to him, whose Youthful Blood
Feels all the stings, of violent Desire?
To him my Lord, to whom Possessions new;
He and his Wife, in their first Charming Bloom,
Can never have Enjoy'd each other long,
How long hast thou been Marry'd?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Ye Gods, ye Gods, let me not think of it!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Nay answer me, I ask it but to serve thee.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Thou seest that I am ready for my Fate;
But let me Dye, as I have Liv'd, a Man,
For thou wilt make a Woman of me,
This very fatal Ev'ning joyn'd our Hands.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This night! this very night! O Earth and Heav'n,
I'st possible? No ne're was Woe like thine!
Thy Wife is then a Virgin, yet untouch'd,
And that thou Lov'st her more than Life it self,
Thy ardent, and thy melting Eyes declare:
Thou for this Night perhaps hast languish'd long,
Or long hast been upon the painful Wreck,
Been tost Alternately, from eager hope
To Mortal fear; from Fear to Hope again,
And we surpriz'd thee in the last Impatience;
Eager for Bliss, and panting to the Goal;
And must Death cut off all thy charming Hope,
Ev'n in th' enchanting height of Expectation?
This is unheard of, this is monstrous Cruelty.
Come, you must melt, my Lord, you shall, you do,
We shall not else be look'd upon as Men;
As men, the very Lyon and the Tyger
Wou'd be less Barbarous, would be less Inhumane,
And here's a sight, that in their Savage breasts
Might raise a tender sense of humane Woe.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: This is indeed deplorable.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord, you utterly forget,
That we our selves have Wives and Children too,
That languish if they Live in hard Captivity,
Tho' where we know not; yet the Powr's above
Behold them, and prepare with dreadful Plagues
To visit our Crimes upon their Innocence,
And all th' injustice, and the crying Cruelty
Which we inflict on this unhappy Pair,
On those poor Innocents will be Reveng'd!

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: I'll hear no more;
For thou wilt melt me, to my Ruin Miramont;
And these by my Distruction thou would'st Save;
Thou know'st the Kings Commands are most severe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And most unjust▪
But Arbitrary Kings, are always Slaves
To Interest: their Implicit grand Command
To all their Subjects, is to advance that,
To which all Orders are suppos'd to tend;
But 'tis the apparent Interest of the King,
To spare this Valiant Youth, which when you shew.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: But how can I shew that?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why would the King destroy him?

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Once more I tell thee;
Because he is his Mortal Foe declar'd,
And is besides the universal Soul
That warms, and moves, and animates these Nations,
T' oppose his vast Designs, whom when they loose
The very Spirit, that supports them gone.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: If he declares for us, they loose him more
Than if he Dies; because we gain him then.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: But he's too Lofty, and too Fierce for that,
He'll ne're declare for us.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: (apart) I would not have him, but I must gain time,
which if I compass, I may yet preserve him
[To Front.] Not Instantly; His Souls too great for that;
But give him time my Lord.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: The English may return, the Angians Rally,
And then, he may be wrested from our hands;
How shou'd I answer that?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Before the Morning they can ne're return;
Give him till point of Day, and let this Fair one
Try her persuasive Pow'r.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Captain?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: The Charge of these two Prisoners must be yours;
But keep your Guard, for Half an Hour at distance;
That their Discourse may not be overheard
If in that time he will declare for us,
Let him be left here with his Beauteous Bride;
But place a guard without that may protect them.
If he refuses, bring him strait to me
And her Convey to th' other Female Captives.
Now Angian, Life or Death are in thy choice;
If thou wilt Swear t' embrace our Interests,
A Glorious Instrument thou mayst become
To make these Nations Subject to our Sway,
And then thou shalt be Happy, shalt be great,
And under us Rule all th' Jroquian Tribes:
If thou Refusest thou shalt surely Die.

div3.head: Scene the 6.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Ah poor Irene!

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Wretched Ulamar!

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: We but just are met—

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: And we must part. Would'st thou not tell me so?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: We must; for ever part.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Who could have thought it!

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Who could have beleiv'd it?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: That wish'd for Happiness should be so near.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: And be so soon, and so entirely lost.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Ah cruel change!

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: O mortal Woe! one Kiss, and then farewel.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: The Gods have giv'n to others to fare well.
O miserably must Irene fare!
Art thou in hast to leave thy Bride for ever?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: My Life! can I avoid it? I must leave thee;
Thou seest the Spousals Cruel Fate prepares for us,
These are the Wedding Joys that Heav'n provides us;
Farewel! A longer stay will quite unman me,
Eternally Farewell—O Cursed parting [Kisses her.
O Charming, earnest of Immortal Bliss,
Which I must ne'er enjoy!

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: The Gods, the Gods reward this Faithless Race.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Me rather Curse, Yes, Curse my damn'd Credulity;
O Fool, fool, fool, to be thus grossly chous'd
By these vile tricking Slaves! O I am lost!
But Justly there's the Torment Justly lost,
I poorly ran the hazard of my Country
To save my House, and on my House the first
The greatest, and most dismal Vengeance Falls.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: But lost Irene's most of all undone,
Consider what I am, and what I was
In the beginning of this Fatal Night;
Was I not Happy?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Thou wast indeed.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: How am I fall'n!

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Oh thou art plung'd in an Abiss of Woe!

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: If I appear to abraid thee Ulamar;
Think there's a wonderous reason for't, who caus'd
This dreadful Revolution in my Fate?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Who but a Dog, who but a Dog?
O I could tear my self!

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Thine is the Fault, but whose must be the Pain?
But whose must be the Horrour?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Oh that it might be mine! might all be mine?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Thy Enemies will soon deliver thee,
And Death will be thy Friend; his Icy hand
Will soon convey thee to that Blissful Land,
Where thou shalt Swim in Everlasting Joy,
Where thou wilt soon forget thy Lov'd Irene.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Oh never! never!

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: The Transitory Pains of Death with thee
Will soon be o're, but I shall feel them long;
Of thy sad Death how long may I be Dying,
For I have neither Enemy, nor Friend
That will deliver me; but must be left
Alone! Oh all alone, I shall be left
Without my Country, and my dear Relations,
Without my Faithful Friends, nay without thee,
Who wert Relations, Country, all to me.
O that thou wert! O that thou would'st be all!

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Thou Miserablest of the Race of Women, What would'st thou?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Thou seest in what Condition I am left,
In what Perfidious, in what Barbarout Hands;
Say, what am I to expect when thou art gone,
From such a Cruel, such a Faithless Race?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Oh Damn them—damn them, O Revenge, Revenege!
I'd give the World that thou wert in my Pow'r

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Say Ulamar, for thou hast known me long;
Say, did I e're appear thus mov'd before?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: No, Never, never; Fate is on thy Brow,
And thy Soul's teeming with some wonderous Birth;
Let it be ne're so dreadful bring it out,
The worst of Fate I have already felt.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: If e'er thou lov'd'st me with a Noble Passion,
'Tis time to shew it now.

sp.speaker: Ul
sp.l: Whither art thou going?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Once more tell me,
Who brought this Load of Woe upon my Head.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Oh Damnation! oh!

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: From whom should my Delieverance then proceed?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Lightning this moment blast me! must I then
Betray my Country, or Abandon thee!

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Say, tho' a poor distressful, Widow'd Virgin,
Yet am I not thy Wife.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: My Dearest Wife!
Dearer then is the Blood that warms my Heart,
But ruin'd Angiae is my Country still.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Wilt thou do nothing for Me Ulamar;
Is not my Honour thine?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: It is, and mine is thine?
And therefore I ll preserve it, true to thee,
To Heav'n and Nature, and to Ruin'd Angiae.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: And I would have thee Constant to them all;
For if thou prov'st a Traytor to the Rest,
Thou wilt be so to me.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Ha! Is there another way to thy Deliverance?
I'll shed the Blood that's Dearest to my Heart
T' obtain it.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: The Blood that's dearest to thy Heart?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: By the great mind I will.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Is not that Blood Irene's?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Thy Blood! O Horrour! what hast thou propos'd?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Yes thou must shed it, Ulamar, and Die.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Am I a Devil?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: What can'st thou stay to expire in fearful Torments,
Insulted o're by these inhuman Slaves;
Thou hast a Ponyard tho' thy Sword is gone.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: I have, and thus I use it. Draws the Dagger, offers to Stab himself.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Hold, by Almighty Love I charge thee hold;
O Look upon me with an Eye of Mercy,
And plunge it here; let me not see thee Die:
Have Mercy Ulamar, and kill me first.

sp.speaker: Ula.
sp.l: What give thee Death? Upon this Sacred Night?
Is that a Bridegroom's gift. The Gods the Gods
Deliver thee, while thus I free my self. [Offers to stab himself.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Thou shault not die, inhumane as thou art;
How could you have the cruel heart t' attempt it?
To leave me here to this perfidious Race:
My Father, Country, Friends, all, all are gone,
And can'st thou leave me too, my Life? Can'st thou?
Can'st thou? Thou shalt not. I will die before thee.

div3.stage: [Snatches the Dagger from him, and offers to kill herself.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: O hold!
That dismal blow I must not, dare not see.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Think what the French when thou art gone▪ Come death▪
And free my Breast from this distracting thought.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Ha Slaves! Is this the use you make of proffer'd Mercy?
Hast! Tear them asunder.
Him to Count Frontenec in Bonds conduct,
And her convey to th' other Female Captives:
Bring them away there.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Ah poor Irene? May the Gods protect thee:
Take in this Dying look my last Farewel;
Death's cruel'st Pang is parting thus from thee.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Oh Gods! What dreadful Fate's reserv'd for me!

div2.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: COme, be not guilty of thy own Destruction!
Believe it, I would gladly be thy Friend;
Besides that, I respect thy wondrous Virtue;
There's something so engaging in thy Person,
That I'm inclin'd with tenderness to Love thee;
But think th' Irrevocable moments fly;
The time approaches when thou must resolve.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: What to Betray my Trust? To be a Villian!

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Mistake me not fond Youth!
Assist us to subdue these Warlike Nations;
And under us thou shalt Command them all.

sp.speaker: Ula.
sp.l: What right have I to rule these Warlike Nations▪

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: The Justest in the World, the right of Nature:
Thou singly hast more Virtue than them all;
And therefore art by Nature form'd to rule them.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: With bare Desert a generous mind is satisfy'd;
If I have Virtue give me leave to keep it?
Complying with thy offer would destroy it,
And I should then have more and blacker Crimes
Than all the warlike Iroquois together;
But thou mistak'st thy Man, I have a Soul
That scorns a Tyrant, and a Slave alike;
And thou would'st have me both:
But since thy offer kindly is design'd;
Ingratitude I doubly will return it.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Return it, say'st thou? How?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Set me but free, and I'll in kind return it.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: In kind?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Yes, Rouze thy self, and shake off this vile Yoak,
Under the which thou bow'st thy Neck and groan'st:
I'll make thee King of all Canadian France,
And the brave English, and the Warlike Iroquois
Shall both support thy Claim.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: I'll hear no more; say, wilt thou Live or Die.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Nay, hear him out; 'tis barbarous to refuse it:
Methinks that I could hear him talk for ever.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Yet be advis'd and Live.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Not on thy terms, I'm not of Life so fond;
Weigh both our offers, and judge which is Juster;
Tyrant and Slave at once thoud'st have me turn,
And weaken and debase my freeborn mind;
That's independant now of all but Heav'n;
And a Superiour in a Man disdains;
The greatest, best of Men are but my equals:
The guilty like thy Master my Inferiours.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Thou hast a noble Soul by Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A Godlike one.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Oh how unlike is what I ask of thee?
I would Establish thee a Lawful King,
And o'er a happy People shalt thou Reign,
Would break thy ignoble Bonds, and give thee means
T' assert thy Liberty, t' assert thy Virtue;
For lurking in thy breast I see the Seeds
Of ev'ry noble Virtue; but by custom
And vain opinion choak'd, and blind obedience
To the unjust ambition of thy Master.
As thou art Man, thou art Generous and Brave,
True Maganimity adorns thy mind,
And thou art as Dearly awful to my Soul
As if thou wert my Father.
But as thou art French, thou art Base, Perfidious, Perjur'd,
And Sacrificest to thy Tyrants will
Thy very Honour, and thy very Virtue.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Mind that my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Thou would'st have me Betray my Trust, my Country,
The Solemn'st and most Sacred of all Trusts.
I would have thee deliver those thou Rul'st,
And free them from the Bonds that wring their Hearts,
And from the Cruel Scourge that makes them Roar:
Should I comply with thee, and should undo
These Generous Nations, who are happy now
In Innocence and Freedom; but would then
Be plung'd in Vice and endless Misery;
How when I afterwards met woful sights,
Deplorable misfortunes, melting Objects;
How would my Heart, within my bosom Die
To think that I had done this:
But thou who hitherto mistaken man,
Hast prostituted to thy Monarchs Pride
The noblest Talents of thy mind and Person,
Thy Wisdom, and thy Courage hast employ'd
To cast all other Nations into Chains,
And Clinch, and Rivet those that bind thy own,
Who hast been Industrous to entail Destruction
Upon the Race of Men, to all Posterity,
Ev'n thy Posterity, thy wretched Children,
If thou hast Children—

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: What Cruel griefs, has that Remembrance Rouz'd?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: How will thy Soul rejoyce when thon shalt come.
To turn those Talents to their Noblest use,
To bring the Nations round to Happy freedom,
And make Attonement to our Indian World,
For all the Woes thy Curst Ambition caus'd!
What Inexpressive Joy will seize thy Breast,
When thou shalt every where meet happy objects,
And think to thee, that Happiness they owe!
To hear the Shouts, the General Acclamations,
Th' unnumber'd Blessings pour'd upon thy Head:
O would'st thy Rouze thy self, and break thy Chain
How would thy Virtue, and thy Glory Shine!
And to what Height thy Happiness would Soar!
Then Impious War should here for ever cease
Which never came among these Happy Groves,
'Till thy false Race, first Landed on our Shoar.
For 'tis for Liberty we War, not Empire;
While at the Blood we spill we hourly sigh,
And Curse the Falshood of detested Slaves,
That rudely force us to Destroy our kind.
How shameful 'tis, that Men whom Heav'n has form'd
Of this vast Universe; the fellow Citizens
Should thus wage Civil and unnatural War:
All Creatures that have Life, but Men agree;
The fiercest and most Savage of the Beasts,
That makes the Forest tremble at his Roar,
Loves his own Figure, in another Beast,
And with him like a Brother Lives in Peace.
Ev'n Fiends themselves with Fiends are ne'er at Variance;
But Barbarous Man, makes Impious War on Man,
And Leagues with Fiends against his fellow Creatures.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: O Godlike Youth! assist me all ye Pow'rs [apart.
Who Love mankind, and who delight in Mercy,
Assist my Just design.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: But if the Justice, of the Noble cause
The freedom of our Indian World won't move thee,
If giving lasting Happiness and Peace
To all the Race of men, won't Rouze thy Blood,
If thy own Fame and Greatness won't prevail,
And if a Crown acquir'd so Brave a way,
Have no Temptations for thy Grovling mind,
Hast thou a Son t' Inherit Bliss or Woe,
For some will for their Children more perform,
Than for themselves; and all the World besides.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A happy thought, ay, urge that motive Home.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Nay, answer me!

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Alas! thou hurt'st me, Probe that Wound no more

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Nay, if thou hast, consider while 'tis time,
On this Important now Depends his Fate,
And by thy Present choice he grows a King,
Becomes a happy and a Glorious King,
Or Lives and Dies a miserable Slave;
Come, I can plainly see thou hast a Son.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes, yes, Brave Youth, we have Children, nay and Wive's,
But shamefully have been afraid to own them,
For fear our mighty Monarch should grow Angry,
And that Vile fear has lost them; if they Live,
They languish in a rude Captivity;
And to retrieve them, and to keep them ours,
We have no hope, but by thy Generous offer.
Come rouze my Lord, how long shall we have Patience:
Have Patience! have Stupidity I would say!
For Patience is a Virtue, this a Vileness,
A very want of Spirits in our Blood:
Come▪ how much longer shall we crouch and Fawn,
Yes Fawn like Dogs, the more, the more we're scourg'd:
But Dogs when Beaten only Fawn on Men
Who were to them Superiour Creatures form'd:
No Dog will fawn upon a Dog who tears him:
Yes, 'tis a sign we have Sacrific'd our Virtue,
Nay, and our very Reason with our Virtue,
When we can thus resolve to offer up
Our Children to the Rage of Lawless Sway.
What is he? That he proudly thus commands us,
Not only to commit the basest Crimes,
To grow the scourge of God, and be the plagues
Of Humane Race, while the French name is grown
A Horrour to each Corner of the Earth;
But that like Devils we our selves should feel
Doubly the Torments we inflict on others;
Should on our Children endless Woes entail,
And grow the Curse ev'n of our own Posterity.
For what? That he o'er Europe may Insult:
Yes, by the Woes of us and our Insult.
What is't to us who Reigns, if we are Wretched?
And can we well be more? Is this our comfort,
That with our selves we make mankind too wretched?
A Comfort fit for Devils, not for Men.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Ay, now thou art my Friend indeed.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Pray where's his Pow'r that aws us into this?
What force has he, but what we fondly give him?
For what he wrongly calls his Pow'r is ours;
And shall we use our Pow'r against our selves:
Would any but a Wretch depriv'd of Reason,
Employ his Limbs to Wound himself and Children,
Because another has the monstrous Cruelty
To tell him 'tis his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: I've heard too much.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: My Lord, to Arms, to Arms!

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: What say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: As we advanc'd towards yonder Southern Gate,
Upon the Mountain fronting it, we spy'd
A Light ascending to the Vault of Heav'n,
Which strait expanding in a general Blaze,
O'erflow'd the Mountain with a Floud of Flame,
And then descending with Impetuous course
Down to the Vale the Fiery Torrent rowl'd,
And now both Hill and Vale appear on Fire:
'Tis thought the Routed Angians who escap'd,
Are now returning with their English Friends,
And by these numerous Lights direct their Nightly March.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Ha! We too in our turn shall be surpriz'd;
And which way move they?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Directly towards the Southern Gate they advance.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Give orders that my Forces be drawn up;
My self I'll lead them to the Southern Gate,
And warmly we'll receive this desperate Foe:
Take care another Band of Fuzileers
Be Planted at the entrance to this place;
They shall receive my pleasure as I pass.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Hold! Let me sec! This Angian Captive yet
Is in my pow'r; how long he may remain so
Heav'n only knows! If he escapes I am lost,
My orders from the Court are so severe,
On this Alarm my Duty calls me hence. [To Ula.
Ten Minutes yet thou hast left thee to declare,
If before they expire, thou wilt be ours,
Thou may'st be happy, else thou know'st thy doom.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The time allow'd thee to resolve is short;
Then I entreat thee make thy dearest use of it.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: I was about it.
Thou say'st thou art my Friend.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I say I am thy Friend: Let Flatterers say
Brave Youth, for I have shewn I am thy Friend;
Live but an hour and thou wilt find me such,
Find I have boldly ventur'd all to save thee;
Done more for thee than ever I would do,
Ev'n for my nearest and most dear Relations;
Thou to my Soul are dearer than them all,
Related to me by a Nobler way;
My Kindred they in Blood, but thou in Virtue:

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Then let me take my leave of my Irene.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thou know'st not what thou ask'st, thy time is short,
And should'st thou see her, thy few pretious moments
Would be in empty Lamentations lost.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Then bind thy self by Solemn Vows to Guard her
From all unworthy usage when I'm gone.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Come, I'll do more for thee;
For thou shalt Live, and be thy self her Guardian:
What can'st thou poorly Die, and thy brave Friends
So near, who come to free thee from these Bonds,
To free us all from our Insulting Tyrant!
Can'st thou desert the great supports of Liberty,
And tamely Die?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Tamely?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ay, Tamely!

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Oh give me but a Sword, and thou shalt see
How Tamely I will fall.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How would'st thou use it.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: I'll thro' thy Numerous Sentries force my way,
And mounting o're the Ramparts Joyn my Friends.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Impossible! Thou would'st betray thy self
And me to Fate, and would'st prevent thy Friends.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: What can I do besides!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Declare.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: What for the French!
Against whose Crimes so Justly thou Inveigh'st?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Do you think I ask thee to Declare for ever?
Thy Sentiments disemble but an Hour.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Is Death so Dreadful?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Consider but the happy Consequence.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: The Consequence is Guilt, Remorse and Shame,
You punish with an Ignominious Death,
They who desert your false and guilty Cause,
And would have me a Fugitive from Truth,
A Fugitive from Virtue?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: But for an Hour.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: But Virtue oft deserted for an Hour,
Resents it deeply, and upon the Wing
Is gone past all return.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Three minutes yet are left thee to Declare.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Then welcome Death the Fourth, for that brings Liberty.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Think that the happiness of ev'n a World
Depends upon thy Life.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Know that Worlds Happiness depends on one
Who will not have it sav'd so base a way.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: If thou art so hard hearted to thy self,
Do something yet for me, who have done for thee,
More than thou know'st, or wouldst with ease believe.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Thou art so Generous, I could Die for thee,
Be satisfy'd with that.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Nay but thou shalt not, thus continue obstinate,
Descend to be intreated for thy self.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: 'Tis they are Obstinate, who are in the wrong:
I never was more Right.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis past; How vain 'tis to contend with Fate.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Where is this Angian?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Count Frontenac our Governour, has sent me
T' enquire of thee for whom thou wilt declare.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: For Liberty.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Then Death shall set thee free:
Here bind him.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Stay yet a Moment.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: I dare not stay,
Our General will be here Immediately,
And when he comes, expects to find him Dead.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Farewell my absent Dear, protect her Heav'n,
And make this gentle to her tender Heart;
'Tis a severe Divorse, but we must bear it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How my Heart Bleeds for him.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Come, away with him

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Wilt thou be good, and think of lost Irene?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Had I an only Daughter, Fair as Virtue,
She should be less my Care.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Farewel my Generous Friend.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Let me Embrace thee, Dearer than my Life,
Dear as my Fame, this Seperation Wounds me,
And makes me Bleed, as if thou wert a part of me,
Dear hapless Youth, eternally Farewel!

div3.head: Scene 5.
div3.stage: Ulamar, Miramont, Sakia, Officer, and Guards.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: He Lives, and the Eternal Pow'rs are Just▪
He Lives, stand off, and let a wretched Mother
Embrace the Joy and Comfort of her Life.
Oh Ulamar, thou darling of my Soul!—

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: What means this Woman with her clamorous fondness:
Present, dispatch him instantly.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Hurt him, and thou shalt be Ten Years a dying.
Where's Miramont?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Shoot him ye Slaves; how dare ye disobey?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Hold! On thy Life forbear! She shall be heard first.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: With this I shall acquaint our Governour.
Do you remain, and Guard your Prisoner well.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Who asks for Miramont?

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Sakia.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sakia?

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Yes; so the Angians call me; but I had
Another Name upon th' Huronian Lake.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Tell now I never saw thee.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: I tell thee 'tis for Miramont I ask.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Men call me Miramont.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Thee? I know thee not.
How long hast thou been here in Canada?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The Sun has five times rowl'd about the Year,
Since first I Landed on your Indian Shoar.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: I want another Captain of thy Name.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: In Canada there is no other Miramont.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: I hou art mistaken; I have often seen him,
And know him well.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Twelve Years ago you may have seen another;
But then his Elder Brother Childless dy'd;
And he return'd to France.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Ye have utterly abandon'd us ye Heav'ns!
And what became of him?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: In France Sev'n years with Honours Crown'd he liv'd,
And then he left it for a better World.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Dead! Is he dead? O the most lost of Women!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Hear me.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Answer me.
Who was that Miramont that Fought this morn
With my poor dying Son?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Twas I: But hear me Madam.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Horrour and Destraction seize me!
Henceforth I'll be as deaf to all the World,
As Heav'n has been to me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Hear me but a word!

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: At length shew mercy ye afflicting Pow'rs,
And send more weight to crush the Wretch you have made▪

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Strange Prepossession!

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: This weight of Woe I cannot, will not bear!
I faint, I die, support thy wretched Mother,
And leave her not in this extream necessity.
Ah Woe! Thou art thy self in dire necessity,
Hopeless, forlorn, of all the World mistaken▪
But who has brought thee to this dismal end.
O wretch, the most Accurst of Heav'n! Thus, thus
I dash against the Ground the fatal cause. [Falls,
And art thou gone, for ever gone my Miramont:
Then all the World is gone with wretched me;
Here let me end my miserable Life:
My miserable Life's already ended,
And I am in the number of those things
That were, and are no more. I come my Miramont! Methinks
I see thy awful Ghost appear,
And beckon me away to that strange Land.
From whence there's no return: Yes now I see thee
Just with that mournful look, that fatal frown,
With which thou now for three successive Nights
Hast broke my dreadful Slumbers, t' upbraid me
For my unkind delay: But I it seems
Flatter'd and cheated by false hope,
Mistook the mortal Summons.

div3.head: Scene 7.
div3.stage: Frontenac, Ulamar, Miramont, Sakia, Officer and Guards.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Ha! Gods! He comes, with the same frown he comes;
Do you call this fancy! O I shall be mad,
I shall be mad with Joy, with Fear, with Wonder!
O thou who hast the Charms to make Death lovely:
What would'st thou with that pale astonish'd look?
Such as the Dying wear, or Dead who arise:
Com'st thou to call thy miserable Wife?
She comes, in life and death thy own Nikaia. [Draws a Dagger.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Nikaia!

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Ha! more Astonishment! He speaks, he calls;
Do you hear? Do you see? Or is this Madness all?

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Oh my Astonish'd Soul! It is Nikaia:

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Again in an afflicted Tone he calls,
I come.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: O hold! [Lays hold on the Dagger.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Ah Gods! He lives, I die; Ah Miramont!

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Thou shalt die here then in these longing Arms;
Dear to my Heart, as the Life-Blood that warms it:
Feel how with Sprightly heats it calls thee back
To Life and Love again▪

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: It is, it is my Miramont!
Oh 'tis too much ye Pow'rs, I connot bear it,
I Die, the mighty Joy devours my Life;
My Love, my Life, my Miramont.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: And doest thou Live? and art thou in my Arms?
Where hast thou past so many Cruel years?
O let these Tears of flowing Joy acquaint thee,
How bitterly I've mourn'd thy fatal Loss!
What hast thou Suffer'd in this rude Captivity?
O thou hast suffer'd what no Tongue can tell?
How hast thou mourn'd for thy afflicted Mate!
For sure thy Grief was equal to thy Love,
And never any Flame could equal thine.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: No we will never, never part again!
Alas I had forgot our Miramont—

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Ha! What of that dear Creature! how I tremble!
Thy looks inform me, that my dearest Hope
The Joy, and Comfort of my Life is lost.

sp.speaker: Sak
sp.l: He Lives, but on the very Brink of Fate:
Alas! They Murder him!

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: They? who!

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: The Barbarous Governour.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: The Governour! my Life! what Governour?

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: The Governour of this new France.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Who has deluded thee?
The Governour of France is in thy Arms.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: The Governour of France is Frontenac;
And art not thou my Miramont?

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: I always was, I always will be thine,
And formerly I was thy Miramont,
But by my Brothers death am Frontenac,
Thus are our names by custom chang'd in France.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: O Horrour! horrour!
O wretch, what dreadful Guilt hast thou escap'd?
Behold thy Son, whom thou art about to Murder?

sp.speaker: Frone.
sp.l: Ha! Where?

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: There, there behold him.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Ha, thy wonder and thy Joy distract thee!
He who stands there, is General of the Angians.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: As sure as he is General of the Angians,
He is thy Son and mine, 'tis thy own Miramont.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: O I am lost and swallow d up in wonder!
Ye Gods, ye Gods!
These are events surpassing, all example;
These are th' amazing Miracles of Fate!
Ha!
Perish all Tyrants, and their black Commands! [Embraces Ul.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Ay, in that Godlike Voice, I hear my Father.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Oh Miramont! my Son, my Son, forgive me!

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: You gave me Life, and you may take it back.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: That Life I gave thee, to defend I'll die;
Dear to my Heart, and lovely to my Eyes!
Come to my Arms once more, Indulge thy Father's fondness,
My Wife, and Son recover'd in an Hour;
And such a Son! O I am Blest
Above my fondest Hope.
I am a God, if nothing intervenes,
To interrupt this more than Mortal Joy;
And thou brave Miramont, my generous Friend,
Thou to whose rare and unexampled Virtue,
I owe the Joy and darling of my Life.
Embrace the worth thou hast sav'd, 'twas thy own Blood, Mira. Embraces Ula.
Which to preserve, thou nobly did'st contend.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: Why woul'st thou drive me to dispair by, saying Front. talks apart with his Son.
My Miramont was in another World.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You would not hear me out.
We esteem this a World distinct from ours.
[Apart.] I must be gone, th' appointed minutes come.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Loose thee, I'll loose my self first.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Your King will have it so, and I must die.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Where are the English?

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Ay, that's my Father's Voice, great Nature's Voice:
Voice of Heav'n is that. What shout is that. [Shout.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: No Matter. Now the Angians are my Friends;
Rally thy flying Squadrons with the morn,

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Before the Sun has finish'd three Careers;
The Warlike English, and th' united Iroquois,
Shall hail thee King of all Canadian France.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: What Sacrifice my Son to Lawless sway!

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: For Fifty rowling Years the wretched French,
Have to their Tyrants Sacrific'd their Sons;
But to rash thoughless Men the Horrours less,
Because th' effect insensibly comes on:
They have been the most abandon'd of all Slaves.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: But I'm a Slave; my aspiring Boy no more.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Oh the blest sound!

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: O I am rous'd from my Lethargick Dream;
And when we have been refresh'd with short repose,
We will to Arms, to glorious Arms my Boy,
And Godlike Liberty shall be the word.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: O that some Angel with his Golden Trump
Would make that Voice thro' the wide World resound;
That the Caelestial sound might rouze Mankind to Liberty!
But ah, these Transports are too Fierce to last;
And th' Angry Gods remand me to my Griefs.
Where's my Irene?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: She comes, she flies to that Enchanting Voice.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: O let me press thee to my very heart;
From which ev'n Fate had not the pow'r to tear thee.
Sir, I us'd no entreaty for my Life;
But for my Love thus low I humbly bow. [Kneels
That you'd consent to make it happy here.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Take her, She's thine; but cherish her like Life;
She merits all thy Love; and more I prize her
For the Rich Dowry of her matchless Virtue;
Than if extended Empire were her lot.

sp.speaker: Sak.
sp.l: O the most blissful hour of all my Life!
My long Calamities be quite forgot,
And let me give up all my Soul to Joy!

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: Where hast thou past this doleful dismal hour;
In dreadful expectation of what Fate
Was terribly about to execute?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Among a Crowd of miserable Slaves;
Where hearing of thy Death in wild Despair;
I made a dire attempt upon my Life,
When gracious Heav'n by Miracle preserv'd me.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: To preserve thee, what God would not appear?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: No, 'twas no God, but 'twas a Godlike Man.

div3.head: Scene 10.
div3.stage: Frontenac, Ulamar, Sakia, Irene, Miramont, Beaufort.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: 'Twas he, by Heav'n, it cou'd be none but he,
Beaufort, thou best of Men, thou best of Friends,
Come to my Arms, come to my Heart my Friend;
This is the wondrous Man to whom I owe [To Front.
My Life, my Liberty, my Fortune, Fame,
And 'tis to him that you my Mother owe.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Too warmly then I never can receive him. [Embrace.

sp.speaker: Ule.
sp.l: Art thou Return'd? Art thou within our Walls?
Where hast thou left thy English?

sp.speaker: Beauf.
sp.l: The English, and your Rallied Angians now
Are most within the Town.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: More Miracles! Astonishing event!

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: Now by my Soul, they'r truly welcome all;
And this exactly to my wish has happen'd;
But without Fighting, how could this be done!

sp.speaker: Beauf.
sp.l: While on the South we made a false Attack,
Brave Miramont upon th' appointed Signal
Gave us admirtance at the Northern Gate.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: The appointed Signal, you amaze me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beauf.
sp.l: Two hours are scarse elaps'd since this brave Man
To me dispatch'd a Messenger express,
Inviting me to come and save my Ulamar,
And for my Entrance gave a certain Signal,
I on the warmest Wings of Frindship flew,
Yet had arriv'd too late with all my Speed,
Had not kind Heav'n in Mercy interpos'd
By this so wonderful Discovery,
With which Brave Miramont has Entertain'd me.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: What say our Souldiers, Miramont?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: They with the English, and the Angians mix,
And Peace and Joy, in all there looks appear:
Impatiently they wait for your Assent,
To cry Hail Frontenac, and Liberty.

sp.speaker: Front.
sp.l: That shall not long be wanting.

sp.speaker: Ul.
sp.l: But now unanimously, thanks we pay,
To thee Brave Miramont, and thee my Beaufort,
O Truly Great! O Truly worthy Son,
Of Great Britania thro' the World renown'd,
For propping falling Liberty,
Supporting sinking Nations!
There is more Excellence, more Godlike greatness
In rescuing one poor wretch from Dire Calamities,
Than in subverting and destroying Empires,
And making Millions wretched.

sp.speaker: Beauf.
sp.l: To Heav'n unanimously praise return,
And thankful for this wonderful deliverance:
Resolve that Heav'n alone shall o're you Rule,
And cast not off your Makers sway for Mans;
Be Govern'd still by Reason and by Law,
And let your Monarch still be Heav'ns Vicegerent,
And execute his Masters will, not his:
Thus Govern'd, we are Absolutely Free,
Heav'n and good Kings give prefect Liberty,
And from this wonderous Night, let all Men learn,
Never to Sacrifice the Publick Good
Either to Foreign, or to Home-bred Tyrants,
For the vile Interest of themselves and Families;
For that upon their Families and selves
Brings certain Ruin: May all France like you [To Front.
Have their Eyes open'd, and with Horrour see,
How to their Tyrants will they offer up
Their Children, and their whole Posterity
The thing which Heav'n and Nature most abhors;
May they see this like you, like you detest it,
Then grow like you, Impatient to be Free,
With us Asserting Godlike Liberty.
